          - (c) one representative of the

                - (i) the National Security Council,

                - (ii) the National Media Commission,

                - (iii) Ministry responsible for Communications, not below the rank  of a director.

sections.title: Duties and liabilities of a member of the Board of the Authority
sections.rawText:
8. (1) A  member  of  the  Board  of  the Authority  has  the  same  fiduciary  relationship  with  the Authority and the same duty to act with  loyalty  and  in good faith as a director of a company incorporated under the Companies Act, 2019 (Act 992).

(2)Without limiting subsection (1), a member of the Board of the Authority has a duty

(a) to act honestly and in the best interest of the Authority in the performance of the functions of the Authority;

- (b) to exercise the degree of care and diligence in the performance of functions that a person in that position would reasonably be expected to exercise in the circumstances;

- (c) not to disclose information acquired in the capacity of the member as a member of the Board of  the Authority  to  any  person  or  make  use  of  that  information,  except  in  the  performance  of functions;

- (d) not to abuse the position of the office; and

- (e) not to pursue personal interests at the expense of the Authority.

- A member of the Board of the Authority, other than the Director General, shall not participate in the day-to-day running of the Authority.

- A member of the Board is not personally liable for damage or  injury to a third party that arises in the execution of an official duty of  that member, if the member at all material times acted in good faith.

- The Authority  shall  indemnify  and  hold  harmless  such  a  member  against  any  legal  costs, including attorney's fees, expenses, and liabilities reasonably incurred in connection with any legal proceedings instituted against the member in respect of acts done or purported to have been done in  the  performance  of  official  duties,  provided  that the  member  acted  in  good  faith  and  in  the interest of the Authority.

- Where a court determines that the Authority has suffered a loss or damage as a result of the act or omission of a member of the Board of the Authority, the court may, in addition to imposing a fine, order the member to pay appropriate compensation to the Authority.

sections.title: Meetings of the Board of the Authority
sections.rawText:
10. (1) The Board of the Authority shall meet at least once every three months for the conduct of business at a time and place determined by the chairperson.

(2) The chairperson shall, at the request in writing of  not less than one-third of the membership of the Board of the Authority, convene an extraordinary meeting of the Board of the Authority at a time and place determined by the chairperson.

(3) The quorum for a meeting of the Board of the Authority is four members of the Board or a greater number determined by the Board in respect of an important matter.

(4) The chairperson shall preside at meetings of the Board of the Authority and in the absence of the chairperson, a member of the Board of the Authority elected by the members present from among their number shall preside.

(5) Matters before the Board of the Authority shall be decided by a majority of the members present and voting and in the event of an equality of votes, the person presiding shall have a casting vote.

(6) The Board of the Authority may co-opt a person to attend a meeting of the Board of the Authority but that person shall not vote on a matter for decision at the meeting.

(7) The proceedings of the Board of the Authority shall not be invalidated by reason of a vacancy among the members or a defect in the appointment or qualification of a member

        - Subject to this section, the Board of the Authority may determine the procedure for the meeting of the Board of the Authority.

impact.reasoning:
This provision consists of two distinct components: (1) a repeal clause that repeals the National Communications Authority Act 2008, and (2) a savings clause that preserves the legal effect of instruments made under the repealed Act, and (3) a Schedule defining the form and content of annual reports.

**Repeal and Savings Clause Analysis:**
Section 37(1) repeals the prior Act, which is a standard legislative housekeeping measure. Section 37(2) is a savings provision—a procedural mechanism ensuring continuity of legal instruments (licenses, frequencies, authorizations, regulations, notices, orders, directions, appointments) made under the repealed Act. This is standard practice in legislative reform to prevent legal disruption and ensure existing regulatory instruments remain valid under the new framework.

The savings clause does not create new substantive powers, impose new obligations, or alter the regulatory regime itself. It merely preserves the legal status of existing instruments during the transition from the old Act to the new Act. This is a technical, transitional provision designed to maintain regulatory continuity.

**Schedule Analysis:**
The Schedule prescribes the form and content of annual reports that the Authority must submit to Parliament (per Section 29). It requires comprehensive disclosure covering:
- Board review and policy objectives
- Performance metrics and actual achievements
- Financial performance and analysis
- Interconnection agreements and license data
- Corporate governance practices and senior management accountability
- External scrutiny (judicial decisions, Auditor-General reports)
- Human resources management
- Procurement and asset management
- Disability compliance and environmental performance

This Schedule enhances transparency and parliamentary oversight by mandating detailed, structured reporting. It does not impose substantive regulatory burdens on external parties (telecommunications operators, service providers, or the public). Rather, it establishes internal governance and accountability mechanisms for the Authority itself.

**Impact Assessment:**

*Digital Innovation:* The Schedule's reporting requirements do not directly affect innovation barriers, compliance costs for tech companies, or market entry conditions. The savings clause preserves existing licenses and authorizations, ensuring continuity for current operators. No negative impact on innovation. **Neutral to low-positive** (transparency supports informed policy).

*Freedom of Speech:* Neither the repeal, savings clause, nor reporting Schedule directly regulate content, speech, or platform operations. No direct impact on freedom of speech. **Neutral**.

*Privacy & Data Rights:* The reporting Schedule requires disclosure of corporate governance, risk management, and fraud measures, but does not impose new data collection, retention, or surveillance requirements on individuals or businesses. The savings clause preserves existing regulatory instruments without expanding surveillance powers. No direct negative impact. **Neutral**.

*Business Environment:* The savings clause is beneficial—it ensures existing licenses and authorizations remain valid, providing legal certainty and continuity for current telecommunications operators. This reduces transition risk and operational disruption. The reporting Schedule imposes administrative obligations on the Authority (not external businesses), enhancing accountability without creating new compliance burdens for operators. **Low-positive** (legal certainty and continuity support business stability).

**Confidence Rationale:**
This is a straightforward procedural and transitional provision with clear, limited scope. The repeal and savings clause are standard legislative mechanics. The reporting Schedule is a transparency mechanism with no direct regulatory impact on external parties. The assessment is highly confident because the provision's effects are transparent and do not involve discretionary powers, vague terms, or enforcement mechanisms that would create ambiguity.

executiveSummary:
The National Communications Authority (Amendment) Bill restructures Ghana's telecommunications regulator with enhanced governance, accountability, and expanded regulatory powers. The bill establishes a reconstituted Board with mandatory gender representation (minimum two women members), four-year renewable terms, and strict conflict-of-interest requirements including public disclosure of registrable interests. The Board gains explicit strategic oversight duties and must establish Technical, Audit, and Risk committees, while an Internal Audit Unit provides ongoing financial oversight.

**Key regulatory expansions raise significant concerns**: The Minister gains authority to create regulations requiring **pre-approval for services using personal data**, potentially creating barriers to digital innovation and raising privacy questions about government oversight of data-driven services. The Minister can also issue written policy directives that the Board must follow, creating tension with the Authority's stated independence—though technical and operational matters remain protected from ministerial interference. Additional ministerial powers cover emergency communications protocols, local content requirements, and universal service standards. The Authority's funding becomes more diversified (fees, parliamentary allocations, investments, donations) with tax exemptions subject to Finance Minister and parliamentary approval, though all borrowing requires ministerial consent.

**Transparency and accountability mechanisms** include quarterly board meetings, public consultation requirements for major decisions, written justifications for board actions, and comprehensive annual reporting to Parliament covering performance, finances, and governance. Board members face removal for conflicts of interest, excessive absences, or failure to disclose interests. The Director-General manages daily operations while remaining accountable to the Board, and staff appointments require presidential approval.

**Business and rights implications**: The pre-approval requirement for data-using services could delay product launches and increase compliance costs for tech companies, startups, and digital service providers. Local content requirements may affect international service providers' operations. However, the bill's emphasis on consumer protection, innovation promotion, and consideration of vulnerable groups suggests balanced regulatory intent. The transition provisions ensure continuity by transferring all assets, liabilities, and existing licenses to the restructured Authority, minimizing disruption to current operators while establishing a more robust regulatory framework for Ghana's evolving communications sector.

analysis.analysis:
The National Communications Authority (Amendment) Bill poses significant challenges to Ghana's digital innovation ecosystem through its introduction of mandatory pre-approval requirements for services processing personal data. This provision fundamentally alters the regulatory landscape by requiring joint evaluation by both the National Communications Authority and the Data Protection Commission before any new telecom-related service involving personal data can launch. For Ghana's growing tech startup sector, this creates a substantial barrier to entry and innovation. Companies developing AI-powered applications, fintech solutions, digital health platforms, or any data-driven services will face extended timelines and increased compliance costs before bringing products to market. This pre-approval bottleneck could discourage entrepreneurship, reduce Ghana's competitiveness in attracting tech investment, and slow the pace of digital transformation across sectors.

The impact extends beyond startups to established technology companies and international digital service providers operating in Ghana. The requirement for dual-agency approval introduces regulatory uncertainty and potential delays that conflict with the rapid development cycles characteristic of the digital economy. Companies may face situations where innovative services are delayed for months during evaluation processes, causing them to lose first-mover advantages or miss market opportunities entirely. The provision's broad scope—covering "all new telecom-related services involving the processing of personal data"—creates ambiguity about which services require approval, potentially leading to over-cautious compliance strategies that further stifle innovation. Additionally, the local content and equity participation requirements may create additional operational constraints for international platforms and digital service providers.

While the bill includes positive elements such as promoting innovation, protecting consumers, and ensuring public consultation on major decisions, these benefits are substantially undermined by the pre-approval mechanism. The enhanced governance structures and transparency requirements may improve regulatory predictability in some areas, but the fundamental shift from a permissive to a restrictive regulatory approach for data-driven services represents a significant setback for digital innovation. Ghana's ambitions to become a regional tech hub could be compromised if entrepreneurs and investors perceive the regulatory environment as overly burdensome compared to neighboring countries with more innovation-friendly frameworks.

The National Communications Authority (Amendment) Bill introduces significant regulatory barriers that will substantially reshape Ghana's telecommunications and digital services business environment. The most consequential change is the mandatory pre-approval requirement for any service processing personal data, requiring joint evaluation by both the National Communications Authority and the Data Protection Commission before launch. This dual-agency gatekeeping process will directly impact technology companies, startups, fintech providers, telecommunications operators, and any business offering AI-powered services or data-driven applications. Companies will face extended time-to-market delays, increased compliance costs for navigating two regulatory bodies simultaneously, and uncertainty about approval criteria—potentially deterring innovation and foreign investment in Ghana's digital economy. For startups and smaller companies with limited resources, these barriers may prove prohibitive, while established players will need to build substantial regulatory affairs capacity.

Additional provisions compound these challenges for businesses. Local content and equity participation requirements may force international service providers to restructure operations, find local partners, or modify their business models to comply with ownership mandates. Universal service obligations could require operators to provide services in commercially unviable areas, affecting profitability calculations. The Minister's authority to issue policy directives to the Board, even with protections for technical matters, introduces regulatory uncertainty as businesses cannot fully predict how ministerial priorities might shift regulatory approaches. Interconnection requirements and emergency communications protocols will require infrastructure investments and operational adjustments, particularly for network operators.

The bill does offer some positive elements for business planning: enhanced transparency through mandatory public consultations, quarterly board meetings, and comprehensive parliamentary reporting should create more predictable regulatory processes; the reconstituted Board with professional governance standards and conflict-of-interest rules may reduce arbitrary decision-making; and explicit mandates to promote innovation and consider consumer protection suggest balanced regulatory intent. Transition provisions ensuring continuity of existing licenses prevent immediate disruption. However, these governance improvements cannot offset the fundamental shift toward pre-market approval and expanded regulatory control. The overall effect is a more restrictive business environment where market entry becomes slower and more expensive, regulatory compliance becomes more complex, and the balance tips decidedly toward control over facilitation of business activity in Ghana's communications sector.

keyConcerns.title: Pre-Approval Bottleneck for All Data-Using Services
keyConcerns.description: This provision requires government pre-licensing approval for "all new telecom-related services involving the processing of personal data"—a category so broad it could encompass most modern digital services, from messaging apps to AI-powered platforms. With no defined approval timelines, decision criteria, or appeal mechanisms, this creates an indefinite gatekeeping bottleneck administered by two separate agencies. Startups and innovators face existential delays while established players can absorb compliance costs, fundamentally shifting Ghana from a "test and learn" innovation environment to a "seek permission first" regime that will deter investment and slow digital economic growth.
